taxon_name.authority: (Nuttall) Kuntze in T. E. von Post and O. Kuntze

place_of_publication.publication_title: in T. E. von Post and O. Kuntze, Lex. Gen. Phan.,

bio:treatment.description: Shrubs, subshrubs, or herbs, sometimes nearly arborescent, perennial, glabrous or pubescent, rarely glandular; taproot woody. Stems matted to spreading, decumbent, or erect, infrequently absent, with or without persistent leaf bases, glabrous or variously pubescent or glandular; caudex stems woody, tightly compact to spreading and at or just below surface, or spreading to erect and above surface; aerial flowering stems arising at nodes of caudex branches, at distal nodes of aerial branches, or directly from root, prostrate or decumbent to erect, slender to stout and usually solid, infrequently slightly to distinctly fistulose and hollow. Leaves basal, sometimes in rosettes, sometimes sheathing up stems, cauline, or basal and cauline, 1 per node or fasciculate on flowering stems, at tips of dwarf branches, or on exposed woody caudices, usually persistent, occasionally persistent through growing season or longer, rarely quickly deciduous; blade glabrous or floccose to tomentose, occasionally also glandular. Inflorescences cymose, cymose-umbellate, umbellate, virgate, or racemose, mostly spreading and open to diffuse, sometimes dense, congested, or compact, sometimes reduced and in subumbellate, subcapitate, or capitate heads or reduced to a single terminal involucre; branches open to diffuse, spreading to erect, usually dichotomously branched except for initial trichotomous node, round and smooth, rarely grooved, angled, or ridged, tomentose to floccose or glabrous, occasionally lanate or glandular, rarely scabrellous; bracts usually 3, connate basally, usually scalelike, sometimes semileaflike or leaflike. Peduncles absent or erect, usually stout. Involucres 1–8 or more per cluster, narrowly turbinate to campanulate; teeth (3–)5–6(–10), erect or occasionally spreading, apex acute to obtuse or rounded. Flowers bisexual or, infrequently, unisexual, not attenuate at base, without stipelike base (except for slightly winged stipelike bases in E. saxatile and E. crocatum); perianth various shades of white, yellow, pink, or red, glabrous, glandular, or variously pubescent abaxially, usually glabrous adaxially except for minute glands and a few scattered hairs; tepals connate only basally or in proximal 1/2, monomorphic or dimorphic; stamens usually exserted, sometimes included; filaments variously pubescent but usually pilose proximally, infrequently glabrous. Achenes light to dark brown, not winged (but nearly so in E. saxatile), 3-gonous, glabrous, occasionally with minutely papillate beak. Seeds: embryo curved.

verbatim.text: Species 107 (101 in the flora): w North America (including nw Mexico), mainly arid regions.

parsed.distribution: w North America (including nw Mexico), mainly arid regions.

bio:treatment.discussion: Species of subg. Eucycla not accounted for in this treatment are: Eriogonum encelioides Reveal & C. A. Hanson, E. fastigiatum Parry, E. molle Greene, E. orcuttianum S. Watson, E. pondii Greene, and E. zapatoense Moran. All are native to Baja California, Mexico.

The keys to species for subg. Eucycla are broken into geographic regions to aid in identification. They are: California (key 1, p. 225); British Columbia, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington (key 2, p. 228); Nevada and Utah (key 3, p. 231); Arizona and New Mexico (key 4, p. 237); Alberta, Colorado, Montana, and Wyoming (key 5, p. 239); and Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Great Plains states, and Texas (key 6, p. 242).

key_statement.description: Flowers with winged stipelike bases.
Perianths white to rose or yellowish; inflorescences cymose, 10–25 × 5–12 cm; achenes 3.5–4 mm; s Coast Ranges, Transverse Ranges, s Sierra Nevada, desert ranges to east
Perianths bright yellow; inflorescences cymose-umbellate, 0.5–3 × 3–8 cm; achenes 2.5–3 mm; Santa Monica Mountains, Ventura County
Flowers without stipelike bases.
Plants forming cespitose or pulvinate mats; inflorescences capitate, or if racemose, subumbellate, cymose, or cymose-umbellate, then plants 0.1–1 dm.
Inflorescences cymose, racemose, subumbellate, cymose-umbellate, or virgate, not capitate.
Perianths glandular-hairy, whitish to reddish; flowering stems glandular-puberulent; Kern and Tulare counties
Perianths glabrous, white to pink or rose, or yellowish with reddish spot; flowering stems not glandular; Inyo and Tulare counties.
Flowers (1.5–)2–2.5 mm; tepals monomorphic; involucres 0.8–1.3 mm; s Sierra Nevada, Olancha Peak
Flowers 3–4 mm; tepals dimorphic, outer globose; involucres 1.5–2 mm; Cottonwood, Last Chance, and Panamint mountains
Inflorescences capitate, rarely umbellate.
Tepals dimorphic, outer often 2 times as wide as inner; scapes floccose to tomentose or lanate or nearly glabrous; common in e and s California
Tepals monomorphic, or if somewhat dimorphic, flowers, involucres, and scapes glandular-pubescent; ec and ne California.
Perianths yellow or ochroleucous to reddish yellow, not white.
Involucres glandular or glandular-hairy; scapes glandular; Sierra Nevada from Placer County to Fresno County and in desert ranges of Inyo and Mono counties, usually above 2500 m
Involucres glabrous or floccose, occasionally glandular; scapes glabrous or glandular; Sierra Nevada and Great Basin; often below 1900 m.

Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic or ovate to obovate, 1–2 × 0.5–1(–1.5) cm; scapes 0.5–1.5(–2) dm, glandular at least proximal to inflorescence; involucres floccose abaxially; clay soils, Lassen County

Leaf blades oblanceolate to spatulate, elliptic or ovate, 0.4–0.8(–1) × 0.15–0.4(–0.6) cm; scapes 0.2–0.8 dm, glabrous; involucres glabrous or sparsely floccose; volcanic soils, Lassen and Modoc counties
Perianths white to rose or pink, not yellow or ochroleucous (except sometimes yellow in E. shockleyi ).
Involucres glandular or pubescent to glandular-puberulent, membranous; c Sierra Nevada and White Mountains, Inyo and Mono counties, 3000–3900 m
Involucres glabrous or tomentose, rigid; s Sierra Nevada, Transverse Ranges, and desert ranges to the east from Mono County s to Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties, typically below 3000 m.
Perianths and achenes pubescent; Last Chance Range, Inyo and Mono counties
Perianths and achenes glabrous; s Sierra Nevada, Transverse Ranges, and desert ranges to the east from Mono County s to Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties
Plants shrubs to subshrubs or spreading to erect perennials, not cespitose or matted; inflorescences branched or, if capitate, plants 1–5 dm.
Involucres 2–10 or more per node or in heads.
Tepals distinctly dimorphic, those of outer whorl to 2 times as wide as those of inner whorl.
Inflorescences cymose-umbellate or capitate; outer tepals globose; Inyo County
Inflorescences umbellate-cymose to cymose; outer tepals not globose; PlumasCounty n to Siskiyou and Modoc counties
Tepals essentially monomorphic, those of outer whorl ca. as wide as those of inner whorl.
Plants herbaceous or woody at base.
Leaf blades lanceolate to lance-ovate, 4–15(–25) cm, villous and green on both surfaces; Sierra Nevada and Great Basin region, Tulare and Mono counties n
Leaf blades oblanceolate to oblong-ovate, ovate, or elliptic, usually 2–6 cm, tomentose abaxially, tomentose or floccose to subglabrous, or glabrous adaxially; widespread.

Involucres (4–)5–7 × 3–8(–10) mm; flowering stems and inflorescence branches glabrous, rarely floccose; inflorescences subcapitate to cymose; leaf blades densely tomentose abaxially, greenish and glabrate adaxially; plants forming large mats; Channel Islands

Involucres (2.5–)3–5(–7) × (1.5–)2–4 mm; flowering stems and inflorescence branches glabrous, floccose, or tomentose; inflorescences capitate to umbellate or cymose; leaf blades variously lanate to tomentose on both surfaces or tomentose to floccose or glabrous adaxially; plants erect, occasionally forming large mats; mainland.

Involucres and flowering stems glabrous or, if tomentose, plants not along the immediate coast; leaf blades variously lanate to tomentose on both surfaces or tomentose, floccose, or glabrous adaxially; plants mostly erect, not forming dense mats; widespread

Involucres and flowering stems tomentose to floccose, rarely glabrous; inflorescences capitate, umbellate, or cymose; leaf blades whitish-lanate to tawny-tomentose on both surfaces, or tomentose to floccose or glabrous and green adaxially; plants forming dense mats; cliffs and bluffs along immediate coast from San Luis Obispo County n
Plants usually shrubs.
Leaf blades narrowly linear or nearly so to oblanceolate, shorter than 2 cm and leaves usually strongly fasciculate; s coastal and desert ranges
Leaf blades linear-oblong to orbiculate or, if linear, longer than 2 cm and leaves not fasciculate; insular or coastal mesas and foothills.
Perianths glabrous; coastal and near-coast areas, Monterey County s to Los Angeles County
Perianths villous; coastal Santa Barbara s to Los Angeles County and insular.
Leaf blades linear to narrowly oblong, 2–4(–5) cm, white-tomentose abaxially, cinereous to glabrate adaxially, margins revolute; Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, and Anacapa islands

Leaf blades ovate or oblong-ovate to ovate or lanceolate to narrowly oblong, 1.5–10 cm, white-tomentulose or tomentose on both surfaces, margins not revolute; coastal regions, Santa Barbara s to Los Angeles County and on Santa Rosa, Santa Catalina, San Clemente, and Santa Barbara islands.

Leaf blades ovate, 1.5–3 × 1–2.5(–3) cm, white-tomentulose; inflorescences congested, capitate; involucres narrowly turbinate; coastal regions, Santa Barbara s to Los Angeles County, and on Santa Rosa islands

Leaf blades oblong-ovate to ovate or lanceolate to narrowly oblong, 2–7(–10) × 1–5 cm, white-tomentose; inflorescences often open, cymose; involucres campanulate; Santa Catalina, San Clemente, and Santa Barbara islands
Involucres 1 per node.
Involucres disposed in elongate racemes at tips of inflorescence branches.
Involucres usually 6–7 mm; plants perennial herbs, (6–)12–18 dm; s Coast Ranges and Transverse Ranges south
Involucres (0.8–)1–6 mm; plants shrubs, subshrubs, or herbs, (1–)1.5–5 dm; widespread.
Plants shrubs; Great Basin region, Mono and n Inyo counties
Plants subshrubs or herbs; widespread.
Plants suffrutescent and much-branched basally; leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic, 0.1–1 cm wide, margins often revolute.
Involucres 0.7–4 mm; flowers 2–4 mm; perianth usually white to pink; widespread
Involucres (4–)5–6 mm; flowers usually 4–5 mm; perianth ochroleucous to rose; Santa Lucia Mountains, Monterey County
Plants not suffrutescent basally; leaf blades rounded to broadly ovate, (0.3–)1–3.5(–4) cm wide, margins not revolute.
Leaf blades round, (0.3–)0.5–1.5 × (0.3–)1–1.5 cm; petioles 1–2 cm; involucres campanulate; Inyo Mountains and Panamint and Coso ranges, Inyo County

Leaf blades elliptic, oblong, ovate, or obovate, 1.5–4.5(–5) × 1–3.5(–4) cm; petioles 1–7 cm; involucres turbinate or turbinate-campanulate; Inyo and White mountains, Mono and Inyo counties s to New York Mountains, San Bernardino County.
Leaf blades elliptic to oblong, (2–)2.5–4.5(–5) × 1.5–3.5(–4) cm; petioles (2–)3–7 cm; involucres turbinate-campanulate, 3–4 × 3–4 mm; White and Inyo mountains, Mono and Inyo counties
Leaf blades elliptic to ovate or obovate, 1.5–4 × 1–2.5 cm; petioles 1–5 cm; involucres turbinate, 3–5 × 2–4 mm; White and Inyo mountains south to New York mountains
Involucres disposed at forks of branching system.
Plants herbaceous perennials.
Leaf blades round-ovate, 0.3–0.5(–1) × 0.3–0.5(–1) cm; Amador County
Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic or ovate, 1–6 × (0.3–)1–4 cm; widespread
Plants subshrubs or shrubs.
Perianths pubescent.
Flowers (2.5–)3–4(–4.5) mm; perianth greenish yellow to yellow; involucres 1.5–2.5(–3) mm, 4-toothed; leaf blades (0.3–)0.5–1.5(–3.5) cm; Imperial and San Diego counties
Flowers 3–6(–7) mm; perianth white; involucres 2–5 mm, 5–8-toothed; leaf blades (0.7–)1.2–5 cm; Del Norte and Plumas counties.
Involucres 3.5–5 mm; Del Norte County
Involucres 2–3 mm; Plumas County
Perianths glabrous.
Inflorescences usually compact, terminally cymose; involucres tomentose, floccose, or glabrous.
Plants erect to spreading subshrubs in montane places, shrubs at lower elevations, 0.2–15 dm; leaf blades (0.3–)1–3.5 cm, margins not revolute, or if so, plants distinctly shrubby; e and s California
Plants spreading or matted subshrubs of desert mountains, 0.5–1.5 dm; leaf blades 0.4–0.6 cm, margins revolute; New York Mountains, San Bernardino County
Inflorescences divaricatedly branched panicles or cymes; involucres glabrous.

Outer tepals obovate to orbiculate; inflorescence branches green, dichotomous, ascending; mountain slopes, s Coast Ranges, Transverse Ranges, s Sierra Nevada, and desert ranges from Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties n to Monterey, San Benito, and Mono counties
Outer tepals obovate; inflorescence branches grayish, mostly horizontal, tiered; desert valleys, Kern County s to e San Diego and eastward
Plants subshrubs or shrubs.
Perianths villous; involucres 3.5–5 mm; peduncles (1–)3–10 cm; Josephine County, Oregon
Perianths glabrous; involucres usually shorter than 3.5 mm; peduncles absent or shorter than 1.5 cm; widespread.
Leaves cauline; widespread
Leaves basal; Deschutes, Harney, Klamath, Lake, and Malheur counties, Oregon.
Plants (3–)3.5–9 dm; perianths greenish white to pale yellow; Malheur County, Oregon
Plants 0.3–1 dm; perianths yellow; Deschutes, Harney, Klamath, and Lake counties, Oregon
Plants herbaceous, sometimes cespitose perennials.
Plants erect to spreading, decumbent, or prostrate, not forming compact, dense, cespitose mats; inflorescences branched.
Perianths usually hairy abaxially, sometimes sparsely so near base.

Leaf blades lanceolate to lanceolate-ovate, 4–15(–25) cm, loosely villous and green on both surfaces; e of Cascade Ranges in e Oregon and Washington e to Elmore and Washington counties, Idaho, and Siskiyou Mountains of s Oregon e into desert ranges of Lake County, Oregon
Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic or ovate, 1–5 cm, densely white-lanate to tomentose on both surfaces, sometimes floccose or glabrous and green adaxially; widespread.

Involucres and flowering stems glabrous or, if tomentose, then inflorescences compound-cymose; leaf blades lanate to tomentose on both surfaces, sometimes floccose or glabrous adaxially; plants not forming dense mats; widespread, s Oregon

Involucres and flowering stems tomentose; inflorescences capitate or cymose; leaf blades densely whitish-lanate or tawny-tomentose on both surfaces; plants forming dense mats; immediate coast, Curry County, Oregon
Perianths glabrous.
Leaf blades linear to oblanceolate; perianths yellow; se Idaho
Leaf blades lanceolate, elliptic to ovate, or oval; perianths white, or if yellow then not of se Idaho.
Tepals dimorphic.

Inflorescences usually not leafy-bracteate, umbellate-cymose to cymose, 1–20 cm; involucres 1 per node, rarely 2–5 per cluster, glabrous or tomentose; perianths white or yellow to rose or purple; petioles rarely twisted
Inflorescences generally leafy-bracteate at least at proximal nodes, cymose, 10–30 cm; involucres 1 per node, tomentose; perianths cream to reddish; petioles often twisted
Tepals monomorphic.
Leaves white-tomentose on both surfaces; Malheur County, Oregon
Leaves not white-tomentose on both surfaces, or if so then not of Malheur County, Oregon.
Involucres and flowering stems glabrous or, if tomentose, inflorescences compound-cymose; leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic or ovate; plants not forming mats; widespread, s Oregon

Involucres and flowering stems tomentose; inflorescences capitate or cymose; leaf blades densely whitish-lanate or tawny-tomentose on both surfaces; plants forming dense mats; immediate coast, Curry County, Oregon
Plants forming compact, dense, pulvinate to cespitose mats; inflorescences capitate, rarely branched.
Inflorescences umbellate, branching sometimes obscured by flowers.
Perianths hairy abaxially; se Washington
Perianths glabrous abaxially; c or se Idaho, or sc Oregon.
Outer tepals ca. 2 times as wide as inner ones; perianths bright white; c Idaho
Outer tepals ca. as wide as inner ones; perianths yellow or ochroleucous; se Idaho or sc Oregon.
Involucres tomentose to floccose; perianths yellow or ochroleucous; leaf blades linear to narrowly oblanceolate, to 7 × 0.5 cm; se Idaho
Involucres glabrous; perianths yellow; leaf blades narrowly oblanceolate to spatulate, to 1.2 × 0.3 cm; sc Oregon
Inflorescences capitate.
Perianths hairy abaxially; achenes pubescent at least at beak; inflorescences typically branched but occasionally seemingly or actually capitate.
Perianths lemon yellow; se Washington
Perianths white to rose or yellow; s Idaho
Flowers glabrous or glandular, not hairy; achenes glabrous, except on beaks; inflorescences usually capitate, rarely umbellate to cymose.
Involucres membranous.
Perianths cream; se Idaho
Perianths pale yellow to yellow; c and w Idaho, or e Oregon.
Perianths pale yellow; flowering stems glandular-hairy; leaf blades white-tomentose and glandular on both surfaces; Wallowa County, Oregon, and Adams and Idaho counties, Idaho

Perianths yellow; flowering stems glandular or thinly floccose to tomentose; leaf blades tomentose on both surfaces or less so and grayish to greenish adaxially, not glandular; Blaine, Butte, Camas, Custer, Lemhi, and Owyhee counties, Idaho, or Malheur County, Oregon.
Flowering stems glandular or thinly floccose; involucres tomentose or glandular; Blaine, Butte, Camas, Custer, Lemhi, and Owyhee counties, Idaho
Flowering stems floccose to tomentose; involucres glabrous except for margins of teeth; Malheur County, Oregon
Involucres rigid.

Tepals dimorphic, those of outer whorl generally 2 times as wide as those of inner whorl or, if dimorphic but less than 2 times as wide, plants of subalpine or alpine habitats, or leaf blades elliptic to round and perianths white to cream or rose

Tepals monomorphic, those of outer whorl ca. as wide as those of inner whorl or, if slightly dimorphic, plants not of subalpine or alpine habitats, or leaf blades oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic and perianths usually yellow.
Inflorescences of 1 involucre atop peduncle; inflorescence bracts absent; Beaverhead Mountains, Lemhi County, Idaho
Inflorescences of 2–8 involucres atop scape; inflorescence bracts subtending cluster of involucres; widespread.
Perianths distinctly pustulose along midribs and base abaxially.
Perianths yellow; Blaine, Butte, Camas, Custer, Lemhi, and Owyhee counties, Idaho
Perianths white to cream; Butte, Clark, Custer, and Lemhi counties, Idaho
Perianths not pustulose abaxially.
Involucres turbinate, 2.5–4.5(–6) × 1.5–2.5(–4) mm; leaf blades (0.2–)1–10(–12).
Flowering stems to 1.4 dm, tomentose; se Idaho
Flowering stems (0.6–)1–4(–5) dm, glabrous or rarely slightly floccose; sw Idaho, se Oregon
Involucres campanulate, 2–4 × 2–4 mm; leaf blades 0.5–1.5 cm.
Involucres (2–)3–4 × (2.5–)3–4 mm, glabrous or floccose only on teeth; flowers 2–3.5(–4) mm, perianth bright yellow; Harney, Lake, and Baker counties, Oregon
Involucres 2–3.5 × 2–3.5 mm, floccose throughout; flowers 1.5–3 mm, perianth yellow; Harney and Lake counties, Oregon
Plants subshrubs or shrubs.
Perianths pubescent.
Leaves not fasciculate, blade lanceolate to elliptic or oblanceolate, tomentose or nearly so; Thousand Lake Mountain, Wayne County, Utah
Leaves usually fasciculate, blade usually oblanceolate, canescent on both surfaces or densely tomentose abaxially and canescent adaxially; s Nevada and sw Utah
Perianths glabrous.
Involucres usually racemosely arranged along tips of inflorescence branches.

Flowering stems and inflorescence branches angled and ribbed or scabrous, or if round and smooth then rigid or stout, glabrous and with short, spinose lateral branches; s Nevada and Washington County, Utah
Flowering stems and inflorescence branches not angled and ribbed or scabrellous or with short, spinose lateral branches, tomentose to floccose or, if glabrous, slender and flexible; widespread.
Leaves fasciculate, blade 0.2–1.5 × 0.25–0.7(–0.9) cm, oblanceolate to elliptic; wc and s Nevada, and Washington County, Utah
Leaves not fasciculate, blade 1.5–3.5 × 0.2–0.8(–1.2) cm, linear-lanceolate or linear-oblanceolate to narrowly oblong; Nevada, s and e Utah.
Leaf blades usually linear-lanceolate to narrowly oblong or narrowly elliptic; inflorescence branches tomentose to floccose or glabrate, occasionally glabrous; e Utah
Leaf blades broadly oblanceolate to broadly elliptic; inflorescence branches usually tomentose; Nevada and s Utah
Involucres dichotomously arranged even at tips of inflorescence branches.
Margins of leaf blades revolute or at least inrolled.
Leaf blades (0.5–)2–6 cm; inflorescences densely branched, usually glabrous; involucres narrowly turbinate, glabrous; San Juan County, Utah
Leaf blades 0.5–1.8(–2.5) cm; inflorescences usually sparsely branched, tomentose to floccose; involucres turbinate to turbinate-campanulate, tomentose to floccose or rarely glabrous; widespread.
Tepals monomorphic; widespread
Tepals dimorphic; e Utah.
Plants 1–2.5 dm; leaf blades oblanceolate, usually thinly tomentose and grayish, rarely glabrous and green adaxially; involucres 2.5–4.5 mm wide; San Juan County, Utah

Plants 0.2–0.8 dm; leaf blades linear-oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic, white- to reddish- or tannish-tomentose adaxially; involucres 1.5–3 mm wide; Carbon, Emery, and Grand counties s to Garfield, San Juan, Sevier, and Wayne counties, Utah
Margins of leaf blades usually plane.
Inflorescences flat-topped and in tiers, branches zigzag; leaf blades tomentose on both surfaces; plants erect; s Clark County, Nevada

Inflorescences usually open, not flat-topped, branches not zigzag; leaf blades variable but typically not tomentose on both surfaces; plants spreading to rounded, typically wider than tall; widespread.
Leaf apices sharply acute; leaf blades usually narrowly elliptic to elliptic, 0.2–1.2 cm wide
Leaf apices acute to rounded; leaf blades lanceolate to oblanceolate or elliptic to oval, cordate, or nearly orbiculate, (0.2–)0.3–3(–3.5) cm wide.
Flowering stems and inflorescence branches tomentose to floccose, rarely subglabrous.
Leaf blades linear-lanceolate to lanceolate, 3.5–7(–9) × 0.3–0.6(–0.8) cm, densely white-tomentose abaxially, less so and greenish adaxially; leaf margins rarely crenulate; Duchesne County, Utah

Leaf blades lanceolate to oblanceolate or elliptic to nearly orbiculate, rarely cordate, 1–5 × (0.3–)0.5–3(–3.5) cm, densely silvery to white-, tannish-, or brownish-tomentose on both surfaces or less so or glabrous and green abaxially; leaf margins occasionally crenulate; not of Duchesne County, Utah.
Leaf blades densely white-, tannish-, or brownish-tomentose on both surfaces or less so or nearly glabrous and green abaxially, (0.5–)1–3(–4.5) cm; Clark County, Nevada, and s and e Utah
Leaf blades densely silvery-tomentose on both surfaces or rarely less so or subglabrous and greenish abaxially, 3–5 cm; Wellington area, Carbon and Emery counties, Utah
Flowering stems and inflorescence branches glabrous.
Leaf blades green and glabrous, rarely thinly floccose adaxially; flowers 3–4 mm, perianth yellow; San Rafael Desert, Emery and Wayne counties, Utah
Leaf blades tomentose to floccose at least on one surface; flowers 1.5–4 mm; perianth usually white, sometimes yellow, cream, or pink; widespread.
Involucres campanulate; leaf blades floccose adaxially, thinly floccose or glabrous abaxially; Nevada
Involucres turbinate; leaf blades variable but always with one surface tomentose; Utah.

Perianths usually yellow to pale yellow, occasionally cream; leaf blades lanceolate to oblanceolate or elliptic, usually densely tomentose on both surfaces, sometimes less so and greenish adaxially; Washington County, Utah
Perianths white; leaf blades lanceolate or broadly elliptic, usually densely tomentose only abaxially; Millard or Uintah counties, Utah.
Plants spreading to somewhat sprawling subshrubs, (1.5–)2–4 dm; leaves commonly basal or sheathing up proximal 1 / 4 of flowering stems, blade broadly elliptic, 1–2(–2.5) cm; Millard County, Utah
Plants erect shrubs, 3–5 dm; leaves cauline, sheathing up proximal 1 / 2 of flowering stems, blade usually lanceolate, 3–6 cm; Uintah County, Utah
Plants herbs.
Plants cespitose, matted, or pulvinate; inflorescences usually capitate.
Perianths hairy.
Achenes tomentose; widespread
Achenes glabrous; c and e Nevada, c, ne, and w Utah.
Flowers 2–2.5(–3) mm; perianth pale yellow to yellow; Emery and Garfield counties, Utah
Flowers 3–4.5 mm; perianth white to rose; e Nevada and ne and w Utah.
Flowering stems spreading to prostrate, (0.5–)1.5–5(–8) cm; leaf blades narrowly elliptic, 0.3–1 × 0.1–0.2(–0.3) cm; e Nevada and w Utah
Flowering stems erect, 0.1–1 cm; leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic, 0.3–0.4 × 0.07–0.1 cm; ne Utah
Perianths glabrous, sparsely pilose, or glandular.
Tepals strongly dimorphic or, if only slightly so, leaf blades oval to rotund
Tepals monomorphic or, if slightly dimorphic, leaf blades not oval to rotund.
Involucre tubes membranous.
Perianths greenish yellow to pale yellow, rarely yellow.

Involucres 2.5–3.5 mm, glabrous or sparsely pubescent with white hairs abaxially; flowers (2.5–)3–3.5 mm; perianths glabrous or sparsely glandular, usually greenish yellow or pale yellow; dry limestone and granitic montane slopes, Elko County and n White Pine County, Nevada

Involucres 2–2.5 mm, sparsely to densely tomentose with scattered glands along ribs; flowers (2–)2.5–3 mm; perianths sparsely glandular, yellow; moist, crusted, sandy, alkaline flats, Ruby Valley, Elko County, Nevada
Perianths white to rose.

Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic, (0.3–)1–1.5(–2) × (0.2–)0.3–0.6 cm, glandular and densely white-tomentose abaxially; involucres 5–7 per cluster, sparsely glandular to glandular-puberulent or pubescent; White Mountains, Esmeralda County, Nevada

Leaf blades oblanceolate to spatulate, 0.2–0.5(–1) × (0.1–)0.2–0.4 cm, glandular and densely white- or greenish-tomentose abaxially; involucres 2–4 per cluster, sparsely glandular-puberulent; Snake Range, White Pine County, Nevada
Involucre tubes rigid.
Leaf blades linear to narrowly oblanceolate or narrowly elliptic, (1.5–)3–9(–12) × 0.1–0.5(–0.7) cm; n Utah.

Leaf blades white- to gray-tomentose abaxially, less so and grayish or occasionally greenish to thinly floccose and bright green adaxially; perianths usually yellow, occasionally ochroleucous; widespread
Leaf blades densely reddish- to brownish-lanate abaxially, less so to tomentose adaxially; perianths ochroleucous, rarely yellow; Cache and n Morgan counties, Utah
Leaf blades lanceolate or oblanceolate to ovate, 0.2–3 × 0.05–1 cm; Nevada or c and n Utah.
Scapes glandular or glandular-hairy.

Involucres sparsely to densely floccose; scapes glandular or glandular only proximal to inflorescences, (0.5–)1–4.5(–5) dm; nw Nevada
Scapes glabrous or tomentose to floccose.
Scapes glabrous.
Leaf margins crenulate or, if plane, leaf blades 1.5–6(–7) cm, scapes 8–25(–30) cm, and plants of s Utah.
Perianths usually greenish white to creamy white or pale yellowish white, rarely pale yellow or yellow; n Utah
Perianths white; s Utah
Leaf margins plane.
Perianths white to pink or rose; Esmeralda County, Nevada
Perianths yellow; Humboldt and Washoe counties, Nevada.

Perianths not pustulose; leaf blades oblanceolate to spatulate or elliptic to ovate, 0.3–1(–1.5) cm; n Washoe and Humboldt counties, Nevada
Scapes tomentose to floccose.
Leaf margins crenulate; Wasatch Mountains, Utah, above 3000 m
Leaf margins not crenulate; Nevada or, if in Utah, below 2800 m.

Perianths cream or yellow, glabrous; not of Esmeralda County, Nevada.
Perianths yellow.

Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic or rarely ovate, 0.4–2(–2.5) cm, densely greenish- to white-tomentose on both surfaces, or densely greenish-white-tomentose abaxially, thinly tomentose and whitish green adaxially; n Nevada and nw Utah.

Perianths pustulose; Washoe County s to Mineral County, e to Humboldt and w Elko counties, Nevada
Perianths cream to white, pink, or rose.

Plants not matted; leaf blades 1–15(–25) × 0.3–6 cm, margins plane; Nevada.

Leaf blades lanceolate to lance-ovate, 4–15(–25) × 1.5–6 cm, loosely villous and green on both surfaces; nw and n Nevada
Perianths glabrous.
Inflorescences with involucres racemosely arranged.
Perianths pale yellow to yellow; flowering stems and inflorescence branches usually glabrous, rarely tomentose, occasionally fistulose; s Utah
Perianths white to rose; flowering stems and inflorescence branches usually tomentose, rarely glabrous, not fistulose; widespread.

Inflorescences with 3–5 racemosely arranged involucres at tips of distalmost inflorescence branches; plants 1–5 dm; c and sw Nevada.

Flowering stems and inflorescence branches usually tomentose to floccose.
